title: Unilateral Utricular Dysfunction Presenting as Disorientation while Driving
chief_complaint: I have a very specific sensation of tilting, but only during high-velocity turns and only when veering leftward. I feel like I might roll the car or fly off the highway.

problem_summary.laterality: Symptoms occur when veering leftward (implicating right side pathology).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Disorientation while driving. No vertigo, nausea, vomiting, tinnitus, or hearing change.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient had to pull over while driving; uncomfortable driving on highways requiring higher speeds.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to return to comfortable driving; previous medications (diazepam, meclizine) were not beneficial.

history.present_illness: 10-month history of tilting sensation during high-speed leftward turns. No precipitating event.
history.otologic_history: No tinnitus or hearing change. Previous audiometry and VNG reported.
history.medical_psych_history: MRI showed nonspecific T2 signal alterations (migraine/small vessel disease differential) and low-lying cerebellar tonsils (Chiari excluded). Labs (CBC, metabolic, thyroid, sed rate) normal. BP 132/80.
history.prior_management: Tried diazepam and meclizine without benefit.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of driving disorientation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity at 250 to 8000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs agreed with PTA. Word recognition scores were excellent.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Normal absolute latencies and interpeak intervals.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG)
tests.key_findings: No spontaneous/gaze nystagmus. Normal tracking, saccades, and OKN. Dix-Hallpike negative. Caloric irrigations within normal limits despite a relative reduction. Fixation suppression was successful.

numeric_results.Caloric Weakness: 22% right relative reduced response (considered within normal limits)

tests.name: Neurotology Physical Examination
tests.key_findings: Head impulse test (HIT) negative bilaterally. Post-headshake nystagmus negative. Romberg: stable on firm and foam, eyes closed. Gait: normal.

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.key_findings: Waveforms obtained and replicated, implying bilateral integrity of the saccule and sacculocollic pathways.

tests.name: Rotational Chair (Standard)
tests.key_findings: Slightly decreased VOR gain with normal symmetry and phase. Step velocity time constants normal. Optokinetic nystagmus was symmetric and within normal limits. Visual-vestibular fixation suppression was intact.

tests.name: Dynamic Subjective Visual Vertical (DSVV) / Centrifugation
tests.key_findings: Abnormal processing of otolith information related to utricular input. Centric rotation showed slight tilt. Eccentric rotation stimulating the right utricle showed NO change in tilt (abnormal). Eccentric rotation stimulating the left utricle showed expected tilt (normal).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity and normal speech recognition bilaterally. Standard vestibular assessment (VNG, cVEMP, standard Rotational Chair) is largely within normal limits, including saccular function. However, specialized Dynamic Subjective Visual Vertical (DSVV) testing reveals a specific right utricular dysfunction, evidenced by a lack of subjective visual vertical tilt when the right utricle is isolated during eccentric rotation.
counseling_points: Your hearing and the majority of your balance system (the canals and the saccule) are functioning normally.
We identified a specific problem with your right utricle, which is the part of the inner ear that senses horizontal movement and tilt.

When you turn left at high speeds, centrifugal force pushes on your right ear. Because that ear isn't sending the correct signal, your brain gets confused about which way is 'up,' causing the sensation that the car is rolling.
This explains why you only feel symptoms during specific driving maneuvers and not in daily life.
Habituation exercises can help retrain your brain to handle these signals better.
notes_for_actor: You are not currently dizzy while sitting in the exam room.
You are anxious about driving on highways because you feel like the car will flip over when you turn left.
You have tried medicines like Valium and Antivert, but they didn't help.
Your gait and general movement are normal.
